references:
Frey, J. K. and T. L. Yates. 1996. Mammalian Diversity in New Mexico. New Mexico Journal of Science
36:4-37

Thompson, B. C., P. J. Crist, J. S. Prior-Magee, R. A. Deitner, D. L. Garber, and M. A. Hughes. 1996. Gap analysis of biological diversity conservation in New Mexico using geographic information systems Research Completion Report, New Mexico Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit, Las Cruces, NM.
Findley, J. S., A. H. Harris, D. E. Wilson, and C. Jones. 1975. Mammals of New Mexico. University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico. 360 pages.
Schmidly, D. J. 2004. The mammals of Texas. Revised ed. University of Texas Press, Austin.
Hall, E. R. 1995. Mammals of Nevada. University of Nevada Press: Las Vegas, Nevada. 710 pp.
Walsberg, G.E. 2000. Small mammals in hot deserts: some generalizations revisited. BioScience 50(2): 109-120.
Hoffmeister, D.F. 1986. Mammals of Arizona. University of Arizona Press. The University of Arizona Press and the Arizona Game and Fish Department, Tucson, Arizona. 602 pages.

Behrends, P., M. Daly and M. I. Wilson. 1986. Range use patterns and spatial relationships of
Merriam's kangaroo rats (Dipodomys merriami). Behaviour 96(3-4): 187-209
Durrant, S.D. 1952. Mammals of Utah: taxonomy and distribution. University of Kansas, Museum of Natural History 6:1-549.
Anderson, S. 1972. Mammals of Chihuahua: Taxonomy and distribution Bulletin of the American Museum of Natural History 148:149-410.
Cockrum, E. Lendell. 1960. The Recent Mammals of Arizona: Their Taxonomy and Distribution. The University of Arizona Press, Tucson, Arizona. 276 Pages.

Beatley, J.C. 1976. Environments of kangaroo rats (Dipodomys) and effects of environmental change
on populations in southern Nevada. Journal of Mammalogy 57(1): 67-93.
habitat_description:
Southwest:
D. merriami is found among cottonwood, willow, western live oak, gray oak, emory oak, Turbinella live oak, mesquite, sycamore, little-leaf sumac, silverleaf and netleaf oaks, rabbitbrush, creosotebush, tarbush, ocotillo, sagebrush, winter-fat, bushmuhly, burrograss, alkali sacaton, dropseed, tobosa, galleta, grama & buffalograss, Apache plume, mesquite, catclaw, blackbush, greasewood, cacti, saltbush, and creosote-lechuguilla associations (Hoffmeister 1986, Hall 1995, Frey and Yates 1996, Thompson et al. 1996, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002).  It occurs in plains grassland, scrub-grassland, Chihuahuan desertscrub, shortgrass plains, sacaton grassland, oak savannah, juniper savannah, mesquite dunes and creosote flats, Mohave Desert scrub, and Sonoran Desert scrub (Thompson et al. 1996, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002).  PNV - Great Basin Desert scrub (Thompson et al. 1996).  It is found in thick rabbitbrush at ~1800m (Thompson et al. 1996). D. merriami is found wherever mesquite grows and the soil is mellow enough for burrows (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002).  Grasses must occur among mesquite and creosotebush and be interspersed with open areas (Thompson et al. 1996).  It eats Festuca octoflora, pepper-grass, goosefoot, mustard, loco-weed, ricegrass seeds, galleta seeds, Penstemon, mesquite, cushion cryptantha, Torrey's desertdandelion seeds, shortstalk stinkweed, annual and perennial three-awns, and annual grama (Hoffmeister 1986, Hall 1995). The species is typically excluded from more friable soils where D. ordii is present, and it is most common on desert pavements and obdurate soils (Thompson et al. 1996).  It occurs on sandy and gravelly soils (NatureServe 2001). D. merriami often burrow in ditchbanks in irrigated valleys and eat a small portion of the grain or seeds (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002).  The home range size in New Mexico is 0.47 ha for males and 0.37 ha for females (New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002).  In Arizona, the home range is 0.13 - 0.20 ha and night movements are up to 150m from the home range center (NatureServe 2001). Elevation is 37-1,982m (Cockrum 1960, Hall 1995). 29-50% of the time is spent within 100 sq. m of the burrow.  Kangaroo rats build their nests at 30-60cm below the soil surface.  In Nevada, the mean precipitation Merriam's kangaroo rats are found in is 139.4mm.  Environmental temperatures higher than 37 C are potentially fatal (Hoffmeister 1986, New Mexico Department of Game and Fish 2002). D. merriami is found in western Arizona and southern Arizona south of the Mogollon Plateau (Hoffmeister 1960). It occurs in western and southern Nevada (Hall 1995). It is present in southwestern New Mexico, in the Pecos and Rio Grande river valleys, and in the Tularosa Basin in New Mexico (Findley et al. 1975, Frey 2004). It occurs in the extreme southwest corner of Utah (Durrant 1952, Utah GAP 1997).
